thread.title: Marne Properties wants $850,000 to remove illegal Abbotsford fence
thread.title_full: Marne Properties wants $850,000 to remove illegal Abbotsford fence

author: TOBY PRIME
title: Marne Properties wants $850,000 to remove illegal Abbotsford fence
text:
SHOCKED residents of a Melbourne apartment block, whose access to their homes is blocked by an illegal fence, claim the developer responsible has demanded $852,000 to remove it.
Yarra Council told News Corp the fence at the Trenerry Crescent, Abbotsford development was built without a permit, but the company responsible is digging its feet in.
Aaron Smith, one of about 80 people who live in the building, said developers at Marne Properties upped the removal bill it plans to charge the body corporate from $511,000 to a whopping $852,000, claiming the original figure was “outdated”.
The fence was erected without notification about seven weeks ago and blocks residents from accessing their front door .
Occupants can only access to the building from an underground carpark or a back lane. Picture: Norm Oorloff Source: News Corp Australia
Pram-pushing parents and a woman in a wheelchair have been forced to dangerously exit the building on to a road, as the fence completely blocks access to the main entrance.
Occupants can only get in and out of the building via an underground carpark or a door off a back lane, which does not have a footpath.
The council has said the fence was not approved and is seeking legal opinion to find a “common sense outcome”.
Mr Smith claimed Marne Properties had previously told residents it would bring the fence down if they bought the land leading to the property’s entrance, which they have used for 10 years.
Fort Knox: residents have been asked to fork out more than $800,000 just to get in their front doors. Picture: Norm Oorloff Source: News Corp Australia
Occupants in the Bradford Yarra Falls Austral Silk (BYFAS) building were informed of the price hike on Friday.
Mr Smith said he wanted the council to force Marne Properties to bring the fence down.
He said it was unlikely residents and the developer would be able to broker an agreement.
“Our best hope is if the council steps in because without the council it is going to be extremely difficult,” Mr Smith said.
Marne Properties has been contacted for comment.
A spokesman for the building company LU Simon has told Melbourne Leader previously the fence was erected within the property boundary and was required by the building and planning permits.
Planning Minister, state Richmond Labor MP Richard Wynne said he hoped common sense would prevail.
Mr Wynne said the council could initiate enforcement action if it believed the fence was illegal.
Originally published as $850,000 to remove a fence?
